text.headline:
Agatha Christie
1890 - 1976
text.text: English writer Agatha Christie, the most prolific female author of all time, was known for her often mind-bending whodunits that kept readers guessing until the end. Her long life was full of fascinating twists, heartbreak, and excitement, and spanned two world wars, a massive economic depression, and the last vestiges of British colonialism.

media.caption: Christie's birthplace and childhood home, Ashfield, in Torquay, Devon

text.headline: Agatha Mary Clarissa Miller is born in Devon, UK
text.text: Agatha spent her early years in the coastal region of Devon, England.

text.headline: The Great War
text.text: Later called World War I shortly after the beginning of World War II, this war was different from any previous in history due to its devastating use of modern technology

media.caption: Archibald Christie in 1915
media.credit: English Heritage media publication, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

text.headline: Agatha Marries Archibald Christie
text.text: Agatha's first husband, Colonel Archibald "Archie" Christie, served in the Royal Artillery.

text.headline: Daughter Rosalind is Born
text.text: Christie's daughter, Rosalind Margaret Clarissa, is born at Ashfield

media.caption: Cover of The Mysterious Affair at Styles

text.headline: First Novel Published
text.text: The Mysterious Affair at Styles is published in the UK, and Christie's first recurring character, Belgian detective Hercule Poirot, is introduced

media.caption: Cover of The Murder of Roger Ackroyd

text.headline: The Murder of Roger Ackroyd Published
text.text: Hercule Poirot appears for a third time in this whodunit, having made his second appearance in the 1923 novel The Murder on the Links

text.headline: Disappearance
text.text: Agatha Christie mysteriously disappears for nearly two weeks in late 1926

text.headline: Travels aboard Orient Express
text.text: Agatha travels aboard the Orient Express to Istanbul, giving her firsthand knowledge of the train ride

media.caption: A crowd gathers outside the New York Stock Exchange after the crash
media.credit: US-gov, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

text.headline: Stock Market Crash
text.text: The Wall Street stock market crashes, causing economic chaos and a depression that spread from the United States to Europe by the early 1930s

media.caption: Agatha and Max at home in 1950
media.credit: National Portrait Gallery, London, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

text.headline: Agatha's Second Marriage
text.text: Agatha marries her second husband, archaeologist Max Mallowan. The two remain married for forty-six years, until Christie's death.

media.caption: Cover of Murder on the Orient Express

text.headline: Murder on the Orient Express is Published
text.text: Christie's iconic character Hercule Poirot embarks on a fateful train journey!

media.caption: Cover of Death on the Nile

text.headline: Death on the Nile is Published
text.text: According to the Smithsonian, an interest in archaeology inspired Agatha in the writing of this novel.

media.caption: June 1944 Allied landing at Omaha Beach in Normandy, France
media.credit: Chief Photographer's Mate (CPHOM) Robert F. Sargent, U.S. Coast Guard, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

text.headline: The Second World War
text.text: Germany invades Poland on 1 September 1939, starting a six-year global war that will cause immeasurable devastation and result in the deaths of millions, including the Nazi mass murder of six million Jews and millions of others they deemed their enemies. After the war ended in Europe in April 1945 with Germany's surrender, it ended globally with Japan's surrender after the United States dropped two atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, destroying the cities and killing as many as 226,000.

media.caption: Cover of And Then There Were None

text.headline: And Then There Were None is Published
text.text: One of the best-selling novels of all time, this story of ten strangers on an island dying one-by-one is a baffling mystery that keeps readers guessing until the end.

text.headline: Stage Play Adaptation of And Then There Were None Premieres in London
text.text: In light of the London Blitz during the Second World War, to avoid bringing down the mood of British theatregoers even further, Christie modified the stage play version of And Then There Were None to make the ending less bleak.

text.headline: India and Pakistan become independent from the British Empire
text.text: After nearly a century of British rule, India and Pakistan become independent states upon the signing of the Indian Independence Act

text.headline: Agatha Christie Dies
text.text: At the age of 85, Agatha Christie passes away in her home, Winterbrook House, in Wallingford, England

text.headline: A Lasting Legacy
text.text: Agatha leaves behind a lasting legacy, from films and television shows adapted from her books, to films and novels about Agatha herself. The Annual Agatha Awards honour mystery novelists each year.
